title: The Team Poised to Play Spoiler in the Postseason
text:
This is the age of the superteam in professional sports, and baseball is no exception. Three teams—the New York Yankees, Houston Astros and Los Angeles Dodgers—could finish the regular season with 105 wins, something that has never happened before. It has created the perception that the upcoming playoffs are little more than an anticlimactic undercard before an inevitable World Series matchup between these top dogs.

The Atlanta Braves see things differently. They’ve spent all year hearing that they exist only to be an early October tuneup for the three teams that actually matter. Contrary to conventional wisdom, the Braves believe somebody could very well could beat the Dodgers, Yankees and Astros—and that “somebody” should be them.

“There’s no such thing as a real superteam in baseball,” veteran Braves reliever Jerry Blevins said. “It’s fun to write about. You want to see this dynasty. You have the Patriots, you have the Warriors, so everybody’s like, ‘Who’s the baseball one?’ But baseball’s just a different animal.”

The first reason to start believing in the Braves is a simple one: They are a ridiculously good baseball team. Maybe not quite as good as the Big 3, but it’s close.

The Braves are on pace to rack up about 100 wins, which would make 2019 the first season in MLB history with four teams reaching the century mark. They rank second in the National League in runs (behind the Dodgers) and fifth in ERA. They’ve won more games than anybody in the majors against opponents with a .500 record or better, giving them a massive lead in what is perhaps the toughest division in the majors.

Their first baseman, Freddie Freeman, is on track to put up 40 home runs and 120-plus RBIs, vaulting him into the MVP conversation. Their 21-year-old outfield prodigy, Ronald Acuña Jr., is on the verge of becoming just the fifth player ever with 40 homers and 40 stolen bases in the same season. Their ace pitcher, 22-year-old right-hander Mike Soroka, has the second-best ERA in baseball at 2.57, only behind the Dodgers’ Hyun-Jin Ryu (2.35).

Atlanta Braves first baseman Freddie Freeman is on track to put up 40 home runs and 120-plus RBIs. Photo: amber searls/Reuters

They’ve done all this while largely avoiding the spotlight, receiving little attention outside of Atlanta as they have dismantled the competition.

“I’d rather go below the radar,” Braves general manager Alex Anthopoulos said. “I just think it’s easier that way. Guys can just focus on going out there and winning each day and not worry about the hype.”

The Braves expected to be in this position. After missing the postseason in four consecutive seasons, they exceeded expectations in 2018 by storming to the NL East title, led by young stars like Acuña and second baseman Ozzie Albies, now 22. Though they lost in four games to the Dodgers in the division series, they accomplished enough for Anthopoulos to declare, “The rebuilding is over, and now it’s all about winning.”

Yet while the Braves believed in themselves, the cold, hard data didn’t believe in the Braves. Pecota, Baseball Prospectus’ sophisticated computer model for forecasting on-field performance, predicted the Braves would land in fourth place in their division with a record 10 games below .500.

Asked about that, Freeman smiled and said, “We didn’t spend $400 million in an off-season,” a jab at the Philadelphia Phillies, who will almost certainly fall short of the postseason despite giving Bryce Harper a $330 million free-agent contract last winter.

“You have a little bit of a chip on your shoulder,” Freeman said. “We went out and proved a lot of people wrong again this year.”

Anthopoulos’s big move came in the form of a $23 million contract to third baseman Josh Donaldson, the largest one-year free agent deal ever awarded to a position player. After an injury-plagued 2018, Donaldson has thrived in Atlanta, posting an OPS above .900 and approaching 40 homers. The Braves struck again in June, snatching up free agent Dallas Keuchel and watching him pitch like an ace over the last month. They bolstered their bullpen at the trade deadline, adding Mark Melancon, Shane Greene and Chris Martin in the span of less than 24 hours.

It’s resulted in the Braves compiling, through Monday, the best record in all of baseball since Memorial Day at 63-34, better than the Astros (62-34), Yankees (63-35) and Dodgers (61-36).

“All it’s about is who’s hot in the playoffs,” Freeman said. “You can play well for 162 games, but once October hits it’s a whole new ballgame.”

That’s why the idea of a superteam is antithetical to baseball compared to other sports. It isn’t that the best team doesn’t always win—it’s that the best team almost always loses.

Mike Soroka has emerged as the ace of the Atlanta Braves. Photo: Scott Taetsch/Getty Images

In the 24 seasons since the creation of the wild card in 1995, the team with the best overall record has failed to win the World Series in 18 of them, or 75% of the time. That includes the 2001 Seattle Mariners (116 regular-season wins), the 2004 St. Louis Cardinals (105) and the 2017 Dodgers (104), all of whom ultimately lost in October. Just making the World Series is far from a guarantee: Since ’95, the team with the top seed in its league has won the pennant just 35% of the time.

The other sports don’t have anywhere near that level of unpredictability in the postseason. Or as Anthopoulos put it, “How many times in the NBA does the 8 seed get to the Finals? And look how many wild-card examples we have.” (One and 12, respectively, since ’95.)

Still, the Braves recognize that as the playoffs begin in a couple of weeks, much of the focus will be on the Yankees, Astros and Dodgers. They’re OK with that. The Dodgers have played in two straight World Series. The Astros won the championship in 2017. The Yankees are the Yankees. The Braves haven’t won a title since 1995.

For that to change, the Braves know what they will have to do: topple the kings.

“Those three teams deserve the recognition they’re getting. It isn’t a fluke,” Donaldson said. “In order for us to get to that level, we’re going to have to win those meaningful games.”

description: The Yankees, Astros and Dodgers are considered baseball’s superteams. But the Braves have quietly built up a powerhouse in Atlanta.
